Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature (T) at any spatial point (x,y) in a region follows the heat equation given by \\(\\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\nabla^2 T\\), where \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity. We study the effects of applying a Fourier transform on the temperature distribution, denoted as \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)\\), and analyze its influence over time.

Given the Fourier transformed temperature distribution \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)(t)\\) at t = T, can we determine the initial temperature distribution at t = 0 without knowing whether the Fourier transform was initially applied?
Explanation: Without knowing whether the Fourier Transform was applied, reconstructing the original spatial temperature distribution T from \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)(t)\\) is uncertain. The transformation might encode the frequencies differently, obscuring the real starting conditions.

causal_map_integration: The temperature distribution at any time, T(x,y,t), influences the temperature distribution at the next time step, T(x,y,t+Δt). The temperature distribution also affects the Laplacian of the temperature, ∇^2 T(x,y,t), which in turn influences the rate of change of temperature, ∂T/∂t. This rate of change of temperature affects the temperature distribution at the next time step. The initial temperature distribution at time t=0, T(x,y,0), influences the temperature distribution at any later time, T(x,y,t).
